Fig. 1 The structure and reactivity of FLP (A) Classical Lewis acid-base pair structure; (B) Frustrated Lewis acid-base pair structure; (C) FLP first activation of H2 reaction; (D) Some reactions of FLP-catalyzed hydrogenation [20]. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (A) General mechanism of acetylene reactions and (B) acetylene adsorption reaction intermediates [27]; (C) General mechanism of hydrogen dissociation and (D) typical hydrogenation reaction mechanisms [29]. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Schematic diagram of selective and non-selective hydrogenation of acetylene[48]. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a)The effects of frustration; (b) The role of FLP in electric fields; (c) Dihydrogen dissociation by electron transfer; (d) Dihydrogen dissociation under the action of an electric field [19]. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Intramolecular (left) and intermolecular (right) FLP-catalyzed hydrogenation reaction pathways for alkynes [69]. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Mechanism of (A) low oxygen vacancy and (B) high oxygen vacancy CeO2-catalyzed acetylene semi-hydrogenation reaction[80]; (C) Mechanism of selective hydrogenation of acetylene catalyzed by CeO2 [81]. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (A) Schematic representation of the solid FLP prompted by the oxygen vacancy construct. (B) Schematic diagram of the action of H2 with FLP. Energy profile of acetylene hydrogenation on (C) CeO2(110) and (D) CeO2(100) [86]. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Energy profiles of acetylene hydrogenation catalyzed by (A) Ga low concentration doping and (B) high concentration doping with CeO2 [89]. (C) Possible schematic of FLP and (D) reaction energy profile of Cu-doped [90]. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (A) Thirteen possible FLP sites present on the crystal faces of anatase TiO2 (101) and (001). (B) Schematic structure of defective and perfect crystal FLP and CLP and the corresponding energy diagrams. (C) The volcano-like relationship between the H2 dissociation energy barrier (eV) and the ICOHP value of the O-H bond [55]. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Mechanism of indium oxide catalyzed hydrogenation reaction (A) CO2 [106]; (B) CH3COOH [108]. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Possible mechanism of catalytic hydrogenation with iron oxides. [57,58]. R. China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. Acetylene semi-hydrogenation reaction is a critical transformation process for removing trace levels of acetylene from industrial ethylene streams. Noble metal catalysts are commonly used for this process; however, their high cost and limited availability hinder large-scale and long-term applications. Non-metallic catalysts, on the contrary, exhibit multiple benefits in acetylene hydrogenation, including higher activity, greater selectivity, and environmental friendliness. This review primarily discusses the use of non-metallic catalysts in acetylene hydrogenation, such as metal oxides, nitrides, and carbon compounds. The emphasis is on the catalytic mechanism and critical steps of non-metallic catalysts based on frustrated Lewis pairs (FLP), including the adsorption and activation of hydrogen and acetylene, as well as ethylene production. In addition, research work on catalyst design and reaction condition modification to improve conversion rate and product selectivity is discussed. Finally, the future development directions of non-metallic catalyzed acetylene hydrogenation are reviewed, including further mechanistic investigations, the study of novel catalytic systems, and the implementation of environmentally friendly chemical processes. It is envisaged that non-metallic catalyzed acetylene hydrogenation would play a key role in energy conversion and the chemical sector, contributing to long-term sustainability. Graphical Abstract These non-metallic catalysts are capable of selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene through the synergistic action of frustrated Lewis pairs. ga1 Keywords Acetylene hydrogenation Non-metallic catalyst Reaction mechanism Frustrated Lewis Pair Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Ethylene is an important measure for judging a country's proficiency in the petrochemical industry. Currently, ethylene is largely produced through the pyrolysis of hydrocarbons such as naphtha and light hydrocarbons. However，trace amounts of acetylene are produced during this pyrolysis, which is a serious problem because its presence in ethylene streams might not only poison later polymerization catalysts but also pose explosive dangers during acetylene polymerization. As a result, the elimination of acetylene is critical [1,2]. Traditionally, noble metal catalysts (Pd, Pt, Ru et al.) have been extensively employed for selective hydrogenation of acetylene, successfully removing acetylene while increasing ethylene production rates, which has led to widespread application [3–5]. However, metal-based catalysts confront several challenges. For starters, the high cost and scarcity of rare metals limit their practical and scientific practicality for large-scale use. Second, metal catalysts may get poisoned, resulting in decreased catalytic activity and selectivity. Furthermore, at high-temperature and high-pressure reaction circumstances, some metal catalysts are prone to corrosion or sintering, decreasing their catalytic lifespan. Finally, due to their high catalytic activity, metal catalysts often generate ethane as the primary byproduct in acetylene hydrogenation processes, which leads to decreased product selectivity. Therefore， to improve catalytic performance in acetylene semi-hydrogenation reactions, researchers must further optimize catalyst structures and surface properties, rationally design reaction conditions, and investigate novel catalytic materials [3,6,7]. In 2006, Douglas W. Stephan's research group reported that bulky phosphorus and boron species could reversibly activate H2 [8]. Subsequently, they discovered that intermolecular and intramolecular phosphine/borane species also exhibited the ability to activate H2 at room temperature ( Fig. 1C) [9,10]. These Lewis acids and bases with spatial hindrance were termed "frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs)" (Fig. 1A,B) [11,12]. In due course, FLPs were found to efficiently activate small molecules such as CO2, H2, alkenes, and alkynes with low activation barriers. Numerous FLP-based catalysts were developed for hydrogenation of unsaturated substrates (e.g., alkenes, alkynes, imines) and CO2 reduction reactions (Fig. 1D) [13–16], thereby initiating the research in non-metallic catalysis. Non-metallic catalysis possesses several advantages and characteristics. Firstly, compared to noble metal catalysts, non-metallic catalysts are abundant and cost-effective, offering reduced ecological impact and potential for sustainable development by means of renewable feedstocks, aligning with the principles of environmentally friendly green chemistry. Secondly, non-metallic catalysts lack isolated metal active sites, leading to excellent resistance to poisoning and enhanced stability. Lastly, the diverse surface functionalities, structures, and morphologies of non-metallic catalysts allow for rational design and tuning to achieve specific bond cleavage and formation, making them highly advantageous for selective catalytic reactions [17–19]. In conclusion, the above characteristics of non-metallic catalysts make them strong candidates for the development of efficient, sustainable and economically viable hydrogenation catalysts. Up till now, FLPs have been explored in the hydrogenation of unsaturated alkynes. [21–24]. For example, Konstantin presented an FLP-type catalyst based on amino boranes for the hydrogenation of unsaturated internal alkynes, which demonstrated good catalytic activity and selectivity in this reaction [25]. Following that, Felix and colleagues reported metal-free cis-selective hydrogenation of alkynes with a boron-oxygen pyridine catalyst, extending the range of FLP catalysis to terminal alkynes [23]. Previously, discussions and research on FLPs were mainly focused on homogeneous catalysis. However, heterogeneous catalysts are more preferred in industrial applications. In this context, non-metallic heterogeneous catalysts like metal oxides and carbon nitrides offer abundant and tunable surface properties, along with inherent "frustration" due to the fixed positions of surface atoms. These features enable the construction of FLPs with active sites akin to those in homogeneous catalysts, facilitating non-metallic catalysis. Consequently, this article primarily investigates recent developments in non-metallic catalysis involving metal oxides, carbon nitrides, and other materials, with a specific focus on understanding the mechanisms of non-metallic hydrogenation. The aim is to provide valuable insights and guidance for the design of catalysts for selective acetylene hydrogenation. 2 Acetylene hydrogenation reaction 2.1 Reaction pathway In general, acetylene hydrogenation has the following reaction paths [26]：. (1) C2H2 + H2 → C2H4 ΔH = −172 kJ·mol−1 (2) C2H4 + H2 → C2H6 ΔH = −136 kJ·mol−1 (3) C2H2 + 2 H2 → C2H6 ΔH = −308 kJ·mol−1 (4) 2 C2H2 + H2 → C4H6 ΔH = −173 kJ·mol−1 (5) nC2H2 + n/2 H2 → (C2H3)n (Oligomerization to produce green oil) And three possible non-hydrogenation reactions (decomposition or polymerization): (6) C2H2→ 2 C+H2 ΔH = −433 kJ·mol−1 (7) C2H4→ C+CH4 ΔH = −125 kJ·mol−1 (8) nC2H4 → (C2H4)- ΔH = −138 kJ·mol−1 Reaction (1) is the primary pathway for obtaining the target product C2H4. However, in active metal catalysts (e.g., Pd), ethylene often fails to desorb or undergoes re-adsorption on the catalyst surface, leading to its continuous hydrogenation and production of ethane (Reaction 2). Furthermore, acetylene strongly adsorbs, leading to the generation of ethylene, butene, etc. (Reactions 3–4), or even polymerizes to produce green oil (Reaction 5). These by-products significantly reduce the selectivity of ethylene, and reaction (6−7) is the main cause of deactivation due to carbon deposition in thermal decomposition of catalyst. Moreover, the formation of ethylene from acetylene hydrogenation is influenced by both kinetic and thermodynamic factors. Thermodynamically, the selective hydrogenation of acetylene (reaction (1)) is an exothermic gaseous reaction with a reduction in the number of gas molecules, implying that low temperatures and high pressures favor the forward direction of the reaction. Kinetically, the alkynyl hydrogenation reaction typically follows the "rake mechanism" ( Fig. 2 A) [27], which illustrates the potential species formed during the alkynyl reaction and how to regulate the reaction towards the desired direction. As shown in the figure below, k2 > >k4 and k1/k-1 > >k3/k-3 promote the adsorption of acetylene, while hinder the competitive adsorption of ethylene with acetylene, and facilitate the successful desorption of the target product. Therefore, to maintain high reaction activity and achieve highly selective ethylene production, the rational design of selective catalysts plays a crucial role in the reaction [3,28]. 2.2 Reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism is a process that seeks to comprehend and elucidate the steps involved in a chemical reaction and the formation of intermediates, which typically encompass adsorption, reaction, and desorption processes. In this section, we elucidate the H2 activation, intermediate formation, and transformation during the acetylene hydrogenation reaction on both metallic and non-metallic catalysts. Moreover, we explore the significance of selective catalysts in this reaction, aiming to offer valuable guidance and insights for catalyst design and optimization. 2.2.1 Metal-catalyzed reaction mechanism A comprehensive understanding of the reaction mechanism of the catalyst is essential for the design of selective catalysts, where the adsorption and activation of H2 play a crucial role in the hydrogenation process. As illustrated in Fig. 2 C, on transition metal catalysts (e.g., Pd, Pt, Rh), H2 can undergo homolytic cleavage to produce two hydrides, following the Horiuti-Polanyi dissociation mechanism (HP mechanism) (Fig. 2D). This mechanism elucidates a sequential hydrogenation process in which hydrogen is incrementally added to the adsorbed acetylene and reaction intermediates, leading to the formation of ethylene and ethane [30,31]. In most cases, H2 adsorbs to the metal sites and undergoes homolytic dissociation. However, when the catalyst consists of monatomic sites, the absence of neighboring metal pairs allows H2 to dissociate only in a heterolytic dissociation manner, where one H atom binds to the metal, and the other binds to heteroatoms of the carriers, such as C, N, and O. This approach has also been shown to follow the HP mechanism and is thus referred to as the pseudo-HP mechanism [32,33]. Additionally, there are some inert metal sites (e.g., Au, Ag) where H2 needs to be cleaved in the presence of adsorbed alkynes, known as the synergistic mechanism [34]. DFT calculations have shown that this mechanism has lower hydrogenation energy barriers than the HP mechanism, although direct experimental evidence is lacking. An alternative reaction mechanism to HP is the unit point adsorption mechanism, known as the Eley-Rideal mechanism, which involves the direct reaction of adsorbed hydrogen on the catalyst with acetylene in the gas phase. Conversely, the adsorption of alkynes with hydrogen on the catalyst in the gas phase often does not allow for direct reaction [35,36]. In addition to H2 activation, the adsorption of acetylene and ethylene on the catalyst significantly influences ethylene selectivity. The differences in the electronic configuration and geometric structure of the active site give rise to various adsorption forms and intermediates of acetylene and ethylene [37] (Fig. 2B). Among them, acetylene adsorbed through π-bonds on the isolated monoatomic Pd shows the highest activity. Initially π-bond adsorbed acetylene can convert into the doubly adsorbed flat-layered acetylene, leading to the formation of a vinyl group, which serves as an essential precursor structure for the product ethylene. Furthermore, ethylene exhibits weak adsorption at this site and can desorb easily. This adsorption mode contributes to achieving high activity and selectivity [27]. Additionally, as depicted in Fig. 2B, the adsorbed intermediates (4−7) serve as precursors for the formation of undesired products like ethane and carbon tetrachloride. To enhance ethylene selectivity and catalyst stability, various studies have been conducted to modify catalysts through the "electronic effect" and "geometrical effect." Among these, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have garnered significant attention. These catalysts are either modified with inert carriers like graphene, nitrogen-rich carbon (C3N4), alumina (Al2O3), etc. to alter the metal morphology and electronic configuration or incorporated into porous materials such as molecular sieves and MOFs to provide a framework for the construction of single-atom sites [38–40]. For instance, Huang et al. [40] prepared Pd/g-C3N4 via atomic layer deposition (ALD), which exhibited not only excellent conversion and selectivity compared to Pd nanoparticles but also a negligible decrease after a 100 h stability test. ALD has been demonstrated as an effective method for synthesizing single-atom catalysts [41]. Moreover, researchers have found that acetylene tends to strongly adsorb at positions such as edges and corners of coordination unsaturation sites. In order to prevent over-hydrogenation and low polymerization reactions, selective poisoning or coverage of part of the active sites with elements like S, B, Pb, CO, etc., has been explored. For instance, Alan J. McCue et al. discovered that sulfur-modified palladium (Pd4S) exhibited unintended selectivity due to partial coverage of the Pd active sites[42,43]. Besides the "poisoning" approach mentioned earlier, adding other metals (e.g., Ag, Au, Cu, Zn, etc.) to form alloys/intermetallic compounds is also an effective method to enhance ethylene selectivity [44–47]. However, the non-uniform distribution of composite metals on the carriers often limits their activity. Furthermore, the subsurface structure of metal catalysts also plays a crucial role in ethylene selectivity. The migration of β-hydroxides generated by H2 cleavage on both the surface and subsurface leads to variations in surface hydrogen concentration, thereby influencing ethylene selectivity. Nevertheless, Detre Teschner et al. demonstrated the possibility of occupying certain sites through compounds like carbons, which promoted Pd separation and improved the selectivity [48,49] ( Fig. 3). Zhang and colleagues synthesized a core-shell Pd@C/CNTs nanomaterial with carbon nanotubes as the support. In comparison to the Pd/CNTs catalyst, this material features a carbon shell that can isolate highly active Pd nanoparticles located at corners or edges, effectively blocking the formation of tetra-substituted carbon intermediates. As a result, the selectivity is significantly enhanced. Furthermore, this catalyst prevents nanoparticle aggregation and coking deactivation, exhibiting excellent catalytic performance over a 100-hour reaction period [50]. The above measures have greatly improved the catalytic performance of palladium-based materials. An overview of the catalytic performance of some modified palladium-based and non-metallic catalytic materials for the semi-hydrogenation of acetylene is given in Table 1. 2.2.2 Non-metallic catalytic reaction mechanism Regarding the discussion on the mechanism of acetylene hydrogenation reaction catalyzed by nonmetallic catalysts, it is essential to address the H2 activation issue. While the ability of metal-based catalysts to activate H2 is well known, it is worth exploring the activation of H2 by nonmetallic catalysts. Among them, a prominent example is the ability of Frustrated Lewis Pairs (FLPs) to dissociate H2 through heterolytic cleavage. Metal-free catalysis originates and develops from this concept, with FLP catalysts being classical examples of metal-free catalysts for small molecule activation and conversion. FLP stands for acid-base pairs comprising of Lewis acids (B, C, P, Al) and Lewis bases (N, P, C, O, S) that cannot form stable adducts due to steric hindrance [63]. Structurally, there are two types of FLP: intermolecular FLP and intramolecular FLP. In intermolecular FLP, the Lewis acids and bases are present in separate molecules, while in intramolecular FLP, the Lewis acids and bases are in the same molecule through covalent bonding connections. In general, FLP can activate H2 by utilizing Lewis acids as electron acceptors to accept the σ electrons provided by the H-H bond, and Lewis bases as electron donors to provide the H-H bond σ * electrons, leading to stretching and breaking of the H-H bond. However, the mechanism involving the intermediate transition state has attracted research interest from scientists. Tibor et al. used DFT calculations to demonstrate that the activation energy of FLP-catalyzed H2 cleavage was significantly reduced compared to the classical Lewis pair (CLP), confirming the role of spatial site resistance [64]. The authors attributed the catalytic effect to the interaction of LA/LB pairs with H2 through electron transfer, as shown in Fig. 4a and Fig. 4c. However, Stefan Grimme et al. suggested that the decrease in the reaction energy of FLP-activated H2 was not sufficiently supported and that the catalytic effect was due to the polarization of H2 by the electric field of the FLP cavity. In other words, H2 entering the FLP cavity dissociates spontaneously. This explanation, known as the electric-field model, was also acknowledged as a new modern view (Fig. 4b,d) [65]. Later, Tibor and his colleagues comparatively studied the two reaction models and finally concluded that the electron model (ET) is superior to the electric field model (EF) [66]. Although FLP has been used to activate alkynes for a long time [67,68], it was only utilized to catalyze the hydrogenation of alkynes in 2013 when Konstantin Chernichenko was inspired by the properties of FLP and the borane-catalyzed hydrogenation of olefins. He proposed a general pathway for the partial hydrogenation of unsaturated alkynes. In this pathway, the alkyne first forms an adduct with borane, and then H2 cleaves in the presence of this adduct and a base to generate intermediates. Protons transfer within the intermediate to form the desired alkene, releasing borane and the base. This pathway was supported by computational analysis, but it is not applicable to terminal alkynes or alkynes with terminal double bonds in their hydrogenation reactions, as terminal alkynes strongly bind to Lewis acids, leading to catalyst deactivation [25]. Until 2020, Felix et al. demonstrated the metal-free hemi-hydrogenation of alkynes using pyridine-boron oxides, where boron and oxygen exhibited similar reactivity to FLP-activated H2. This study enabled the hemi-hydrogenation of terminal alkynes through FLP catalysis [23]. Additionally, Liu et al. achieved the hemi-hydrogenation of terminal alkynes by reducing the strength of Lewis acidity in FLP catalysis, resulting in > 99% conversion and selectivity [24]. This emphasized the significance of Lewis acidity in FLP catalysts and expanded the applicability of FLP. Subsequently, Ye and McEwen focused their research on the semi-hydrogenation of terminal alkynes, exploring the performance of various FLP catalysts in acetylene hydrogenation. Although these catalysts exhibited promising hydrogenation activity, they faced challenges such as strong binding to alkynes and the susceptibility to deactivation by electron-rich macromolecular ligands. To address these issues, the researchers proposed several strategies to prevent FLP catalyst deactivation during terminal alkyne hydrogenation. In summary, these strategies include weakening the binding between terminal alkynes and hydrogen gas, increasing the binding affinity of macromolecular ligands, and altering the binding mode using metal as a Lewis acid site [57]. Finally, in this paper, the authors summarized the catalytic cycle of both intramolecular and intermolecular FLP catalysis for terminal alkyne semi-hydrogenation, as depicted in Fig. 5. Regardless of whether the reaction occurs intramolecularly or intermolecularly, it involves three key steps: (1) alkyne insertion, (2) H2 heterolysis, and (3) intramolecular protonation [57]. Such FLP-type catalysts should be designed with multiphase catalytic neighborhoods in mind rather than just homogeneous catalysis, and the next section will go into more detail on this connection and its potential uses. 3 Non-metallic catalysts Currently, multiphase non-metallic catalysts are used in several major applications, including oxides, sulfides, nitrides, and carbon materials. etc. These materials are cost-effective and readily available, and their catalytic performance can be controlled by adjusting the composition, morphology, crystal structure, etc., enabling highly selective conversion of acetylene. The diverse attributes of non-metallic catalysts make them a promising alternative to overcome the limitations of traditional metal catalysts. 3.1 Metal oxide catalysts Metal oxides play a crucial role in catalysis due to their high specific surface area, abundant surface defect sites, and tunable acid-base properties. These distinctive features have expanded their applications beyond being mere carriers, making them versatile multi-phase catalysts that can be directly utilized in catalytic reactions [70]. 3.1.1 Cerium oxide Due to its redox property of being able to transform between Ce3+ and Ce4+, its unique acid-base characteristics, and its fluorite structure, cerium oxide (CeO2) has been utilized in various catalytic applications [71]. In the past, CeO2 was primarily used as a catalyst in oxidation reactions and occasionally as a carrier or stabilizer in hydrogenation reactions [72–74]. However, in recent times, researchers and scholars have recognized the intriguing properties of CeO2, leading to its expanded application as a catalyst in acetylene hydrogenation reactions. In 2012, the group of Gianvito reported the application of the metal oxide CeO2 to the acetylene selective hydrogenation reaction, achieving an acetylene conversion of 86% and an ethylene selectivity of 81%, which opened a new field of research for researchers [50]. Subsequently, the group focused on the mechanism of CeO2 hydrogenation, proposing that H2 and C2H2 co-adsorb on oxygen atoms, and the oxygen atoms stabilize the β-C2H2 radical hydrogenation to produce ethylene, serving as the active centers for reactants and intermediate hydrogenation. Consequently, the oxygen vacancies generated by excessive reduction are not conducive to the reaction. Additionally, CeO2 (111) crystal surface exhibits higher hydrogenation activity compared to CeO2 (110) crystal surface, possibly due to more oxygen vacancies and defective sites. Furthermore, Gianvito et al. successfully loaded CeO2 on TiO2, achieving up to 90% acetylene conversion. This catalyst demonstrates excellent hydrogenation performance and sustains stable hydrogenation for several hours [51,75,76]. After Gianvito 's group, Melchor et al. proposed a new mechanism for CeO2 hydrogenation, “associative mechanism”, in which H2 is cleaved through the heterogeneous dissociation pathway, and the transfer of H atoms leads to homogeneous dissociation products as the final products. The M-O bonding and reducibility of metal ions play a decisive role in the hydrogenation products, as metal oxides containing M-O bonds facilitate hydrogen heterogeneous dissociation, and the reducible capacity of metal cations determines the final form of hydrogenation products. Additionally, it is noted that adsorbed hydrogen not only serves as a hydrogen source but also restricts acetylene oligomerization on fully reduced and hydroxylated surfaces [77,78]. However, addressing the question of whether hydrogen transfer permeates into the CeO2 bulk phase or remains only at the surface, Werner et al. conducted a specific study on the interaction between H2 and the CeO2(111) crystalline surface on CeO2(111) thin films, revealing that on oxidized CeO2 surfaces, H is predominantly retained at the surface as hydroxyl groups, whereas in reduced CeO2−x, H mainly infiltrates into the bulk phase, where oxygen vacancies are crucial for generating hydrides from CeO2−x, promoting H infiltration and stabilizing hydride species formed by H in the bulk phase [79]. In the absence of a fully established reaction mechanism for the hydrogenation of CeO2, advanced and modern characterization tools have been employed in the study of this catalytic mechanism. Wu's group conducted a comprehensive study on the mechanism of CeO2 catalyzed acetylene hydrogenation using in-situ inelastic neutron scattering (INS) and in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFT), which resulted in the fact that both the surface species of CeO2, O-H and Ce-H, directly participated in the reaction, and that the Ce-H species were more reactive than O-H as well as that the degree of CeO2 reduction corresponded to the different reaction results. It is possible that CeO2 treated with H2 at 673 K can lead to the occurrence of oligomerization of ethene due to its strong adsorption, or even deactivate the catalyst. Furthermore, by analyzing the combined results of INS and DRIFT, the researchers elucidated the mechanism of acetylene hemi-hydrogenation at different oxygen vacancy concentrations ( Fig. 6A-B). On cerium oxide catalysts with low concentrations of oxygen vacancies, acetylene obtained ethylene products by acquiring two H atoms from bridged OH, while on cerium oxide with high concentrations of oxygen vacancies, acetylene obtained H from Ce-H species and OH [80]. However, Cao et al. conducted a comprehensive mechanistic study of CeO2-catalyzed hydrogenation via DRIFT and found that under reaction conditions where CeO2 is reduced and strongly hydroxylated on the surface, both exposed O and Ce sites chemisorbed C2H2 and hydrogenated to form stable C2H3 * intermediates, with the desorption of the product C2H4 being the limiting step, with the O site exhibiting higher reactivity than the Ce site. They showed that in the O site, πbond adsorption of HCCH species is the main active species for the stepwise hydrogenation to C2H4 (Fig. 6C) [81]. Due to the significantly higher energy barrier (∼3 eV) and kinetic limitations in the hydrogenation pathway of H2 homogeneous dissociation to produce two hydroxyl groups, and the relatively less hindered hydrogenation pathway of H2 heterogeneous dissociation to produce hydrides, it has given rise to a wider range of theoretical calculations and experimental studies [82–84]. Researchers have proposed that frustrated Lewis acid-base Pairs (FLPs) can be constructed in metal oxides containing oxygen vacancies. These FLPs consist of spatially site-blocked Lewis acids (LAs) and Lewis bases (LBs) that can reversibly activate small-molecule H2 and promote H2 heterogeneous dissociation [8]. For example, in 2017, Zhang et al. constructed FLPs at porous cerium oxide surface defects with two adjacent Ce3+ as LA sites and lattice oxygen as LB sites. This construction ultimately dissociated the H-H bond with a low activation energy of 0.17 eV, indicating that the catalytic activity would be enhanced with the concentration of oxygen vacancies [85]. Zheng et al. performed a comprehensive study of CeO2(100) and CeO2(111) surfaces using DFT calculations. The results confirmed that adjusting surface oxygen vacancies effectively enhances the acid-base properties of Lewis acid-base pairs and increases the distance between Lewis pairs (Ce-O), resulting in the growth of H-H bond adsorbed on the acid-base sites. Thus, the activation barrier of H2 is lowered, facilitating H2 heterogeneous dissociation ( Fig. 7). Additionally, the researchers proposed a specific pathway for acetylenic hydrogenation in the FLP site: C2H2 begins with the attack of hydride adsorbed on the Ce site, and the reaction intermediate, C2H3 * , prefers to bind to the Ce site rather than the O site, avoiding possible C-O bond breakage [86]. Due to the high temperatures required for pure oxide-catalyzed hydrogenation reactions, researchers have attempted to lower the reaction temperature by doping oxides with other metal atoms. Gianvito first reported the excellent hydrogenation properties of CeO2, but the reaction required a high temperature of 523 K for optimal results. Consequently, the group tried doping Ga into CeO2, forming the composite oxide Ce95Ga5OX, which reduced the reaction temperature to 373 K. The addition of Ga was presumed to induce H2 dissociation, thus lowering the H2 activation energy barrier, but it resulted in detrimental oxygen vacancies in the overall acetylene hydrogenation process [52,87]. Additionally, Julia et al. demonstrated that the concentration of oxygen vacancies in CeO2 increases with the increase of doped Ga content, and Ga-O-Ce sites formed by the introduction of Ga have much lower H-H bond breaking activation energy compared to ordinary CeO2 [88]. Zhou et al. conducted a comparative study on the H2 dissociation mode and acetylene hydrogenation performance of CeO2(111) doped with low concentration of Ga (<2%) and high concentration of Ga (2–10%). The results showed that doped Ga favored the generation of oxygen vacancies and facilitated the construction of FLPs, and the active site Ga/O-FLP showed higher hydrogenation activity than Ce/O-FLP. Interestingly, in low concentration doped GaL-CeO2 catalysts, H2 on Ga/O-FLP sites dissociates very easily (0.13 eV) but is limited by the second step of hydrogenation (0.88 eV); whereas Ce/O-FLP sites are limited directly in the first step of hydrogenation (0.75 eV) ( Fig. 8A-B). Furthermore, the H in M-H will not be transferred to the O sites, but the Ga-H can be transferred to Ce. In highly doped GaH-CeO2, H from Ce-H species is transferred to the neighboring O, and Ga-H hydride is stabilized. Overall, low concentration doping has little effect on the CeO2(111) hydrogenation activity, while high concentration doping significantly enhances the CeO2(111) hydrogenation activity [89]. Additionally, as shown in the Fig. 8C-D, the researchers doped CeO2 with Cu and examined the hydrogenation properties of the Cu-CeO2(111) crystalline surface. They observed that Cu doping induced oxygen vacancies by causing ligand unsaturation in the CeO2 lattice. The formation of oxygen vacancies promoted the potential existence of three FLPs (Cu/O5, Cu/O6, and Ce/O6) on this surface, which facilitated H2 dissociation. Computational studies demonstrated that H2 dissociation preferably occurred on Cu/O5, with lower energy barriers, resulting in the formation of Cu-H hydrides and O-H groups. Notably, the researchers identified the hydrogenation of the C2H3 * intermediate as the rate-controlling step throughout the hydrogenation process. Moreover, the addition of Cu not only enhanced the dissociation of H2 but also significantly reduced the hydrogenation energy barrier in the second step [90]. Riley et al. also proposed to lower the reaction temperature by doping Ni with CeO2. They compared the hydrogenation performance of Ni-CeO2 catalysts synthesized by four different methods: wet impregnation, co-precipitation, solution combustion, and sol-gel synthesis. The results showed that the catalysts achieved 100% conversion with high ethylene selectivity. Among the methods, sol-gel synthesis exhibited the best catalyst preparation. The authors further explained that the high catalytic activity resulted from Ni doping of CeO2, which facilitated the generation of oxygen vacancies, beneficial for the construction of FLP. However, during the catalytic process, Ni did not directly participate in the reaction; it only facilitated the creation of the active site [53,54]. Xie et al. investigated the role of oxygen vacancies and hydroxyl groups using Ni/CeO2-nanorods (R), Ni/CeO2-nanocubes (C), and Ni/CeO2-nano-octahedra (O) as hydrogenation catalysts. They proposed a CO2 hydrogenation mechanism for FLP. The researchers suggested that the FLP is constructed by the presence of oxygen vacancies (as Lewis bases) and hydroxyl groups immobilized at a certain distance from the impeded hydroxyl group (Lewis acids). This construction greatly enhances the adsorption capacity and hydrogenation performance of CO2 over the catalyst [91]. However, recent research suggests that oxygen vacancies may have adverse effects in the acetylene reaction. Li et al. employing a combination of in-situ spectroscopic characterization and Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations, have confirmed the complete hydroxylation of cerium oxide surfaces. Their work establishes that acetylene molecules can interact with these surface hydroxyl groups, leading to the production of ethylene. Additionally, it is proposed that surface oxygen vacancies, in conjunction with hydride species, are detrimental to the selectivity of ethylene. Although acetylene readily undergoes hydrogenation on CeO2 surfaces containing oxygen vacancies, it simultaneously promotes the hydrogenation of ethylene, potentially resulting in ethane formation or even the generation of polymeric compounds. Consequently, unreduced cerium oxide catalyzes the hydrogenation of acetylene with a notably high selectivity for ethylene production [92]. Currently, research on CeO2-catalyzed acetylene hydrogenation is well-established. The mechanistic explanation centers mostly around the available oxygen vacancies on the catalyst's surface, which motivate the formation of the FLP structure, enabling H2 dissociation for hydrogenation. However, the process's acetylene absorption and desorption remain unclear, along with the need for experimental and characterization techniques to justify its high selectivity. 3.1.2 Titanium oxide Titanium oxide is another metal oxide that has been extensively studied due to its similar surface properties to cerium oxide and its wide range of applications in catalysis. The various applications of TiO2 in hydrogenation reactions have prompted researchers to investigate the role of H2 on its surface [93–95]. It is well known that H2 dissociation on metal oxides involves two main mechanisms: homogeneous dissociation and heterogeneous dissociation. Hu et al. used DFT to calculate the activation of H2 on the surface of various crystalline TiO2, and the results indicated that kinetically H2 tends to undergo heterogeneous dissociation to produce hydroxyls and hydrides, while thermodynamically it more easily undergoes homogeneous dissociation to produce hydroxyls. Additionally, on the rutile surface, which has the most stable structure, the hydride formed is not stable, and the hydrogen on Ti-H is transferred to O. This study elucidates the mechanism of H2 dissociation on TiO2 [96]. Wei et al. further determined that H2 dissociation on rutile TiO2 follows the heterogeneous dissociation pathway, producing hydride-proton pairs. Subsequent hydrogen transfer leads to the reduction of Ti atoms, but the energy required for the transfer process is higher than that for the dissociation process. Therefore, the possibility of the existence of heterogeneous dissociation products is higher [97]. There are significant differences in the amount of oxygen vacancies in TiO2 after treatment with different atmospheres. Notably, in H2-treated TiO2, the oxygen vacancies adsorb H to form a Ti-H-Ti structure, which resembles a hydride. This structure efficiently reduces CO2 to HCOOH, as the H from these hydrides directly triggers the hydrogenation reaction of CO2 [98]. The ability of TiO2 to activate H2 has also been applied in acetylene hydrogenation reactions. Wan et al. investigated TiO2 (101) and TiO2 (001) crystal surfaces, where the tetra ligand Ti atoms exposed after creating oxygen vacancies on the surface acted as LA sites, while the non-adjacent O atoms acted as LB sites. A total of 13 potential FLPs were identified ( Fig. 9 A), and after screening, only 6 effective FLPs were found. In these effective FLPs, H2 dissociates through a heterogeneous dissociation, with significantly lower dissociation energy compared to the homogeneous dissociation mode. And that OV-5–1 has the lowest activation energy among these FLP sites, which is the most favorable for the activation of dissociated hydrogen (green region of Fig. 9B). Furthermore, it was observed that H2 dissociates more readily at the FLP site exposed to oxygen vacancies (0.23ev) than at the FLP site without oxygen vacancies (0.98ev) or the CLP (1.08ev) (Fig. 9 C). Subsequent studies revealed that the presence of oxygen vacancies indeed enhances hydrogenation performance, but the hydrogenation process is still limited by the hydrogenation of C2H3 * intermediates. Therefore, regulating the interaction between C2H3 * and the catalyst surface becomes necessary [55]. From the above studies, it was found that oxygen vacancies play a significant role in the hydrogenation reaction, triggering a series of investigations on modified titanium oxides. Generally speaking，methods to enhance the generation of oxygen vacancies in titanium oxide typically include heat treatment under reducing or oxygen-deficient atmospheres, ion doping, and chemical reduction [99–101]. These approaches lead to the formation of defective titanium oxides, thus improving their catalytic performance. Xin et al. obtained TiO2−X-T with varying Ti3+ contents by post-annealing TiO2 at different temperatures. A variety of characterizations demonstrated that the post-annealed TiO2−X-T maintained a typical anatase structure without undergoing phase transformation, effectively controlling the concentration and location of Ti3+ in the desired region. This straightforward post-treatment proves to be an effective method for managing Ti3+ concentration and positioning [102]. Wang et al. presented a method for preparing oxygen-rich vacancy-deficient SnO2/TiO2 composites through in-situ hydrolysis and thermal synthesis, which loads SnO2 on TiO2, leading Sn4+ to occupy Ti4+ positions and exposing more defects. This process provides catalytic active sites for the reaction [103]. Donga et al. prepared Ti0.5Sn0.5O2 mixed oxides by co-precipitation method, which were used to load VOX oxides to prepare VOX/ Ti0.5Sn0.5O2 catalysts, the weak acidity of VOX is the main reason for the good catalytic performance of the catalysts as well as the resistance to the toxicity of water vapors [104]. Saravanan et al. prepared TiO2 @SnO2 catalysts by combining sol-gel and thermal decomposition methods, which showed better hydrogen storage performance compared to pure TiO2 due to the generation of oxygen vacancy defects after the composite oxides and the reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+, which is a key component for greater hydrogen adsorption capacity [105]. Oxygen vacancy is a crucial active site in titanium oxide, endowed with catalytic activity. It has always held a pivotal position in photocatalysis. However, there has been relatively limited research on its involvement in thermal catalytic hydrogenation of acetylene and other reduction reactions, as well as its applications in other mechanisms. More extensive investigations are warranted in the future, focusing on the modification of titanium oxide to optimize oxygen vacancies in the material's structure and surface chemistry. 3.1.3 Indium oxide Indium oxide (In2O3) is a typical surface FLP catalyst after cerium oxide (CeO2), which was first discovered by Ghuman who found that indium hydroxide In2O3−x(OH)y has a structure similar to the catalytic properties of FLP, in which the surface OH is the Lewis base site, and the In atoms near the oxygen vacancies are the Lewis acid sites ( Fig. 10A). The ability of the two to catalyze the reduction of CO2 by H2 to produce CO and H2O was calculated to show that the reduction of CO2 is the rate-limiting step of the reaction, and that the desorption of H2O leads to a change in the surface acid-base sites, which in turn affects the active sites [106]. And then, Yan et al. who used solvothermal synthesis to prepare BiXIn2−XO3 materials with Bi3+ homo-crystalline substitution of In3+, which showed an increase in acid active sites and catalytic activity compared to In2O3−X(OH)y or In2O3 [107]. With the above example of In2O3 activation of H2 reaction, the researchers applied it in acetylene hydrogenation and observed that In2O3 exhibited higher selectivity (about 85%) for ethylene generation from acetylene. The authors propose that this reaction involves a synergistic effect between In atoms, neighboring O atoms, and oxygen vacancies, with all three components playing indispensable roles. They affirmed the significant role of oxygen vacancies but noted that it differs from the role of oxygen vacancies alone [56]. Additionally, in the selective hydrogenation of acetic acid to ethanol catalyzed by In2O3, Lyu et al. found that the oxygen vacancies on the surface of In2O3 (110) not only promoted CH3COO* hydrogenation but also played a key role in C-O bond breaking. They highlighted that oxygen-vacancy In2O3 behaves differently from conventional metal catalysts (e.g., Cu, Ru) typically used for this reaction. Moreover, In2O3 with oxygen defects exhibits a lower hydrogenation energy barrier (0.21 eV) compared to conventional metal catalysts (e.g., Cu, Ru) for catalyzing this reaction, facilitating the hydrogenation and desorption of the key intermediate CH3CHO* (Fig. 10B) [108]. 3.1.4 Iron oxide In the last century, research on the catalytic hydrogenation of alkynes using iron complex catalysts was mainly conducted. However, it was constrained by harsh reaction conditions, a narrow range of applications, and low selectivity [109–112]. Currently, direct application of iron oxides in alkynes is quite limited, but some progress has been made. In these types of iron oxide catalysts, at most cases, variable iron acts as the acid site, while the hydroxyl group on the neighboring metal functions as the base site. This synergistic combination allows for the cleavage of H2 and adsorption of acetylene, leading to the conversion of acetylene to ethylene during the hydrogenation reaction. For instance，Tejeda-Serrano et al. utilized a one-pot redox method to prepare nFeOX-TiO2 catalysts. These catalysts not only reduced the reaction temperature (<150 °C) but also achieved industrial-grade yields and selectivity (>99%) for catalyzing the acetylene hydrogenation reaction, surpassing other loaded non-precious-metal-based catalysts. It was hypothesized that on these catalysts, H2 and alkyne undergo double-site or competitive adsorption, while the hydroxyl group on the acidic oxide TiO2 promotes H2 heterogeneous dissociation ( Fig. 11A) [57,58]. Moreover，Gou et al. catalyzed the acetylene hydrogenation reaction using FeOX as the active center, obtaining excellent results with 100% acetylene conversion and 82% ethylene selectivity. It was hypothesized that the catalyst formed a special ring complex through a variety of characterization techniques, namely Fe II -HO-Fe III, which can effectively dissociate H2 and adsorb acetylene to generate ethylene (Fig. 11B) [59]. One of the crucial factors that cannot be ignored for oxide catalysts is the presence of oxygen defects. Niu et al. conducted a comparative study on the catalytic activity of several structurally similar FeO, γ-Fe2O3, α-Fe2O3, and Fe3O4 in the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. They found that these catalysts exhibited high hydrotreating activity, which was attributed to the oxygen vacancies generated on their surfaces. Furthermore, Fe3O4 showed significantly higher activity than FeO and Fe2O3 due to its higher reducibility, leading to the generation of more oxygen vacancies. However, there is an optimal value for the degree of oxygen vacancies [113]. Rodrigo et al. investigated the chemical environment of CeO2 lattice doped with various levels of Fe3+ using a range of characterization techniques (e.g., Raman spectroscopy, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance, etc.). They demonstrated that the lattice becomes unsaturated due to the substitution of Ce4+ by Fe3+, and the electrically neutral mechanism necessitates charge compensation through the creation of oxygen vacancies. As a result, Fe3+ doping leads to an increase in the concentration of oxygen vacancies [114,115]. 3.1.5 Other oxides The irreducible oxides SiO2, Al2O3, MgO, etc., have historically been used primarily as catalyst support materials due to their low hydrogenation activity. Recent research has refuted this idea, showing that these oxides can exhibit catalytic activity in specific situations. Wischert et al. have discovered that on the surface of γ-Al2O3, both Al and O can activate CH4, leading to the production of Al-CH3 with OH. This activation is attributed to the synergistic interaction of surface Lewis acid-base pairs. The researchers observed that water molecules not only contribute to the alkalinity of O during the process but also stabilize the reaction [116,117]. V. Zakharova et al. metallized the surface of mesoporous silica-based molecular sieves and further grafted or impregnated them with conventional amines and phosphines (e.g., diethylenetriamine, triethylamine, and tetramethylpiperidine etc.) to create solid-loaded Lewis acid-base pairs that remained stable in air. The results demonstrated that the catalysts exhibited good CO2 adsorption capacity, and the solid systems with grafted Lewis acid and Lewis base generally showed higher CO2 adsorption capacity compared to those impregnated with Lewis base [118]. In general, H2 tends to undergo heterogeneous dissociation on these irreducible oxides, resulting in the creation of stable surface hydrides [119–121]. In order to study the dissociation process of H2, Steeve Chretien et al. used lanthanum oxide (La2O3) as a model for non-reducible oxides. They suggested that the development of a hydroxyl group from the adsorption of a single hydrogen atom causes the appearance of a polarization of La atoms close to the hydroxyl group. A hydroxyl and hydride species are created when both hydrogen atoms are adsorbed. These results are consistent with the idea that H2 undergoes heterogeneous dissociation [122]. The dissociation products of H2 may not always exist in a stable condition on reducible oxides, though. An investigation of the interaction between H2 and ZnO was done by Hong Shi et al. They found an unexpected discovery using calculations based on density functional theory (DFT) and in-situ scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) characterisation. At very low temperatures, H2 can fracture into a chain-like structure, which is followed by the creation of dissociated species independently at the Zn and O sites [123]. 3.2 Carbon-based catalyst Due to the issues of excessive activity and poor selectivity associated with metal-based catalysts, it is crucial to seek alternative materials for catalysts. The focus of research has shifted to carbon catalysts, a non-metallic and environmentally friendly substance, in response to social needs. 3.2.1 Graphene Graphene is a two-dimensional carbon nanomaterial consisting of carbon atoms in sp² hybridized orbitals arranged in a hexagonal honeycomb lattice. Its excellent properties make it inherently catalytic, but researchers have discovered that the catalytic performance can be further enhanced by controlling the position of active sites in its structure, doping with heteroatoms or functional groups, and other approaches. This has led to extensive research on the synthesis and modification of this new nanocarbon material in recent years [17,124,125]. In 2014, Ana Primo conducted a comparative investigation on a series of graphene (Gr) catalytic materials. The TPD characterization results revealed a strong interaction between H2 and Gr. However, the mechanism of H2 activation on Gr remains unclear. Inspired by recent work on the activation of small molecules, such as H2, by FLP, the authors hypothesized that independent acidic and basic sites exist on Gr at certain distances from each other. The acid-base pairs formed by these sites promote H2 dissociation. The authors did not provide a specific explanation of how the hindered Lewis base-pair functions. Nevertheless, they performed acid-base site titrations on Gr using CO2 and NH3, and the results indicated that the effects of CO2 and NH3 on Gr are irreversible. This study suggests the potential of non-metallic catalyst Gr materials as alternatives to precious metals [126]. Then, Sun investigated the activation of hydrogen molecules using boron and nitrogen co-doped bilayer graphene (BN-G) and graphene strips (BN-Gr) as FLP catalysts, and calculations showed that the active centers of this catalyst are the dopant-adjacent carbon atoms, and the H2 heterogeneous dissociation of H is one by one up to the carbon atoms [127]. In addition，The research team led by A.A. Abakumov employed hydrazine treatment to produce nitrogen-doped graphene oxide (N-RGO). They observed that this catalyst exhibited excellent performance in the semi-hydrogenation of acetylene, achieving an impressive 97% ethylene selectivity. However, when compared to palladium-based catalysts, this particular catalyst required a reaction temperature exceeding 200 °C to deliver optimal results [128]. Furthermore, the research group conducted a comparative analysis of the catalytic properties of hydrazine hydrate and hydrogen thermal reduction of graphene oxide. They suggested that nitrogen doping could diminish catalytic performance, while the presence of oxygen-containing functional groups such as hydroxyl and ketone appeared to enhance catalytic activity. Nevertheless, the authors did not provide a definitive explanation for this mechanism [60]. Mihaela-Mirela investigated the hydrogenation activity of graphene in the catalysis of aromatic, conjugated nitro, and other compounds. They hypothesized that the active site is a FLP, where the acid site may be related to carbon vacancies or carboxylate groups, while the base site may be a carboxylate group. Furthermore, they observed a significant reduction in the hydrogenation activity of graphene after treatment with acetic acid. This reduction is likely caused by the neutralization of the base site by acetic acid. In contrast, the FLP is a simultaneous effect of the acid and base sites, and this may contribute to the reduction in activity [61]. Not all acid-base pairs in graphene can function as FLP; only those acid-base pairs with a suitable distance from the H-H bond can effectively activate hydrogen. Therefore, the design of FLP sites is crucial for this non-metallic hydrogenation process. Liu et al. utilized boron-fluorine for constructing a real metal-free multiphase FLP catalyst ( Fig. 12A). They introduced eight acidic functional groups to modify the edges of nitrogen-doped Z-shaped graphene. In this design, boron acts as an acidic site, and nitrogen serves as an alkaline site to successfully create the FLP. The resulting structure can easily catalyze the heterogeneous dissociation of H2 with a lower energy barrier. The difference among various functional groups primarily affects the impact of acidity on the activation energy barriers. When applied in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, it was observed that acidity also influences the dissociation energy of H2. Specifically, active sites with high acidity exhibit a low dissociation energy for H2, resulting in a decrease in the energy required for the hydrogenation reaction, showing a positive correlation (Fig. 12B-C) [129]. The above studies have demonstrated the catalytic performance of FLP-type carbon catalysts. 3.2.2 Carbon nanotube (CNT) Carbon nanotubes are nanoscale tubular carbon-based materials that are highly valued in the catalysis industry due to their low porosity, great heat stability, and readily accessible surfaces [130]. They have long served as supports for catalysts. For instance, nitrogen-doped hybrid nanomaterials of Co0/Co3O4 @NCNTs were created by Wei et al. using a thermal reduction technique. The homogeneous distribution of C, N, Co, and O species inside the framework of carbon nanotubes was confirmed by thorough characterization. Hydrogenation activity was increased by the potent interactions between Co-O-C and Co-N-C bonds, which decreased the dissociation energy of H2 in the graphene layers. By using this catalyst to hydrogenate nitroaromatic compounds, researchers were able to achieve outstanding activity and chemical selectivity of over 99% [131]. It was suggested that both Co0 and N-doping had a promoting effect on hydrogenation activity, but the exact active site of this catalyst has not been conclusively determined. Wei employed in-situ synthesis and post-nitridation treatment to prepare a series of metal-free N-doped carbon nanotubes. Extensive characterization and DFT calculations indicated that the post-nitridation treated N-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) retained their structure and morphology without significant changes. These treated NCNTs exhibited a larger specific surface area, increased pore volume, and more defects. However, it was found that defects were not the primary reason for the hydrogenation activity of NCNTs. Instead, pyridinic nitrogen sites were identified as the main active sites for hydrogenation. In this hydrogenation process, pyridinic nitrogen, due to its higher electronegativity compared to carbon atoms, interacted with H+ while carbon atoms bonded with H-. This led to the heterolytic cleavage of H2, and nitrobenzene followed a "direct reaction pathway," undergoing successive hydrogenation and dehydrogenation steps to form aniline [132]. Recently, the application of graphene in hydrogenation reactions has sparked interest among researchers in the catalytic activity of carbon nanotubes. Igor B. Bychko's research group was the first to report the use of carbon nanotubes in ethylene hydrogenation reactions. This catalyst exhibited excellent stability under high-temperature hydrogenation conditions. Subsequently, researchers explored the use of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) in acetylene selective hydrogenation reactions. They discovered that the surface of heat-treated MWCNT-400 exhibited high defects, low oxygen content, and an alkaline surface in the presence of hydroxyl and carbonyl groups. This surface property facilitated a high reaction rate for acetylene at 350 °C, with a selectivity of up to 85% for ethylene. Two possible active sites for this reaction were proposed: one related to frustrated Lewis pair (FLP) capable of activating small H2 molecules, and the other based on π-π interactions involving the triple/double bonds on the graphene basal plane [133,134]. 3.2.3 Carbon nitride Nitrogen-doped carbon materials, such as carbon nitride, can effectively regulate the charge distribution of carbon atoms and create active sites to achieve excellent hydrogenation performance [135,136]. However, the current applications of such materials are mainly focused on the hydrogenation of liquid-phase aromatic hydrocarbons and organic acids, with few applications in alkynes. Therefore, the content of this section is intended to serve as an introduction to metal-free catalysts using carbon nitride, with potential application in alkynes' selective hydrogenation reactions in the future. Zhang et al. designed several hindered Lewis pair catalysts (Al@N-Gr-1, Al@N-Gr-2, and Al@C2N) primarily composed of aluminum atoms and nitrogen-doped carbon materials, which exhibit excellent catalytic activity. The CO2 hydrogenation over these catalysts occurs via three main steps: first, H2 by heterogeneous dissociation generates H-C/N with H-Al species, then H on the H-Al species transfers to adsorbed CO2, producing HCO2 * , and finally, a second H2 activation occurs, where HCO2 * gains another H to form HCOOH [137]. Zhu et al. conducted a systematic study on more than ten M/C2N (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, and Pt) to comprehend the nature of the FLP sites, the mechanism of H2 molecular cleavage, and the pathway of H* transfer in metal atom-doped nitrogen carbide materials. The results indicated weak chemical adsorption of H2 on these metal sites, with adsorption energies highly dependent on the electron affinity of the metal atoms and the acidity of the metal sites. The heterogeneous dissociation energies of H2 ranged from 0.14 to 0.49 eV, and the calculations revealed that the low heterogeneous dissociation energies of H2 were jointly determined by the electron transfer between the H2 molecule and the Lewis acid-base pairs, as well as the localized electric field of M/C2N. Among these materials, Pd/C2N and Ni/C2N exhibited lower activation energies associated with the exothermic process and were selected for subsequent acetylene hydrogenation reactions [138]. Wan et al. attempted to create FLPs in 2D materials, such as carbon-nitrides (g-C3N4 and C2N). Due to the electron-providing nature of the C-N bond, which acts as a natural Lewis base site, the researchers believed that introducing Lewis acids (LAs) at a certain distance from the Lewis base (e.g., Al and B, which are typical electron-deficient groups) would allow for the formation of FLPs. They found that Al-N FLPs exhibited lower H2 activation barriers (∼0.03–0.53 eV) with better hydrogenation activity than B-N FLPs. However, the entire acetylene hydrogenation process encountered a higher energy barrier (∼0.96 eV) during the second step of C2H3 * hydrogenation, possibly due to strong C2H3 * adsorption on Al and a robust H+–N bond. The structure-property relationship regarding the N site requires further elucidation [139]. 3.3 Other non-metallic catalysts Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of emerging porous materials with variable and tunable microenvironments, which can effectively immobilize active sites to achieve various catalytic effects. They hold great potential for applications in catalysis. María Tejeda-Serrano employed a novel synthesis method called post-synthesis (PS), wherein a specific metal-organic framework (MOF) is first selected, and then functional active sites are incorporated into the inner wall channels of the MOF. In their study, the researchers successfully embedded FeIII-OH2 as functional active sites into the MOF material and utilized it as a catalyst in the acetylene hydrogenation reaction. They demonstrated that acetylene can be adsorbed stably on the catalyst through acid-base interactions, leading to a more favorable hydrotreating behavior compared to ethylene [58]. Zheng et al. employed a stepwise anchoring strategy to sequentially bond hindered Lewis pairs (LPs) to MOF materials. The strong ligand interactions between LPs and MOF effectively stabilized LPs on the MOF sites, leading to certain catalytic activity. Additionally, the catalytic reactions exhibited high selectivity attributed to the specific size and pore effects [140]. Dong et al. proposed the modulation of the electronic properties and structure of PdSX in UiO-66 to achieve acetylene semi-hydrogenation reaction with high selectivity [141]. Furthermore, Ye et al. designed functionalized UiO-66-X materials, incorporating both acid and base functional groups within the MOF frameworks. They performed calculations to study the cleavage of H2 and the hydrogenation barriers in CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The results revealed interesting BEP (Brønsted-Evans-Polanyi) relationships between the hydrogenation potential barriers and the H2 adsorption energy or the hydride attachment energy of the acid sites. In other words, the larger the charge carried by a unit of electric charge, the greater the energy associated with that charge, thereby altering the activation energy of the reaction. [142]. From the above studies, it is evident that constructing Lewis acid and Lewis base sites in these microenvironmentally tunable porous materials to form FLP structures is facile and facilitates the promotion of hydrogenation reactions. In addition to MOFs, another structure with similarities is the "sulfur-containing metal cluster." This structure involves direct interconnection of one or more metal atoms and sulfur atoms to form metal-sulfur bonds, providing a high specific surface area and homogeneity, and enabling highly dispersed active sites. For instance, Fu et al. discovered that pure Ni-based catalysts had relatively low selectivity. However, when Ni was immobilized within Mo3S4 clusters to form a NiMoS catalyst, the catalytic system achieved 100% acetylene conversion with 90% high selectivity. Moreover, the catalyst remained stable over a 16-hour reaction time without deactivation issues like coking and carbon buildup. The researchers further noted that H2 dissociation occurred over the catalyst. Furthermore, the researchers observed that heterolytic cleavage of H facilitated the dissociation of H2 on the catalyst, promoting the successive hydrogenation of acetylene adsorbed with π-bonds to produce ethylene. This alteration in the reaction pathway, compared to the previous homolytic cleavage of Ni atoms in H2 to form two H atoms, resulted in lower energy barriers and increased reactivity advantages [62]. 4 Summary and outlook In this review, the primary focus is to present a comprehensive summary of the research progress of non-metallic catalysts in acetylene hydrogenation reactions. Non-metallic catalysts offer new and promising possibilities for such reactions, thanks to their advantages of being cost-effective, utilizing abundant resources, having tunable catalytic properties, and exhibiting high selectivity. Despite the remarkable advancements of non-metallic catalysts in acetylene hydrogenation reactions, there remain certain challenges that require attention. 1. A key issue is understanding the reaction mechanism and active sites of non-metallic catalysts. Further experimental and theoretical studies are necessary to unveil their catalytic mechanisms. Although FLP (Frustrated Lewis Pairs) offer a pathway for metal-free hydrogenation, a unified model is still needed to explain the catalytic processes, including adsorption, activation, and detachment of non-metallic catalysts in the future. Such a model would provide a more accurate strategy for designing non-metallic catalysts. 2. The stability and lifetime of non-metallic catalysts pose challenges, particularly in practical applications under high-temperature and high-pressure conditions. Efforts are required to enhance the stability of these catalysts to ensure their longevity and durability in real-world scenarios. 3. The design and synthesis methods of non-metallic catalysts need further improvement to achieve higher catalytic activity and selectivity. Developing innovative approaches in the design and synthesis of these catalysts will contribute to enhancing their performance and efficiency in acetylene hydrogenation reactions. Overall, non-metallic catalysts hold great potential in acetylene hydrogenation reactions, but addressing those issues through deeper research and development will pave the way for their successful application in industrial and environmental contexts. coredata.dc:description: Acetylene semi-hydrogenation reaction is a critical transformation process for removing trace levels of acetylene from industrial ethylene streams. Noble metal catalysts are commonly used for this process; however, their high cost and limited availability hinder large-scale and long-term applications. Non-metallic catalysts, on the contrary, exhibit multiple benefits in acetylene hydrogenation, including higher activity, greater selectivity, and environmental friendliness. This review primarily discusses the use of non-metallic catalysts in acetylene hydrogenation, such as metal oxides, nitrides, and carbon compounds. The emphasis is on the catalytic mechanism and critical steps of non-metallic catalysts based on frustrated Lewis pairs (FLP), including the adsorption and activation of hydrogen and acetylene, as well as ethylene production. In addition, research work on catalyst design and reaction condition modification to improve conversion rate and product selectivity is discussed. Finally, the future development directions of non-metallic catalyzed acetylene hydrogenation are reviewed, including further mechanistic investigations, the study of novel catalytic systems, and the implementation of environmentally friendly chemical processes. It is envisaged that non-metallic catalyzed acetylene hydrogenation would play a key role in energy conversion and the chemical sector, contributing to long-term sustainability.
coredata.dc:title: Advances and mechanistic insights in the catalytic semi-hydrogenation of acetylene over non-metallic catalysts
